newsitem.title: JAPAN: Crudes drift sideways in quiet Asia, Dubai softer.
newsitem.headline: Crudes drift sideways in quiet Asia, Dubai softer.

text.p: Crude oil prices drifted sideways in extremely quiet trade on Thursday in Asia, amidst a dearth of market leading factors and participants, due to the Christmas holidays, traders said.
"The market is dead quiet, lacking direction with overseas futures markets closed," a broker said.
NYMEX energy markets will resume trade later on Thursday, while the IPE will reopen on Friday for a shortened trading session ending at 1730 GMT.
Cash February Brent was notionally assessed at $23.35/23.45 unchanged from late Tuesday U.S. levels.
Dubai inter-month spreads were assessed weaker as the remaining estimated four to five wet February cargoes are not expected to attract buying interest unless prices come down, traders said.
February/March Dubai was assessed at about 35/45 cents and March/April at 45/55 cents, compared to previous levels of 45/55 cents and 55/65 cents, respectively.
Sellers of February Dubai are targetting full month quotes plus about 80 cents, whilst buyers are seen aiming for below 70 cents, traders said.
Traders expect the Brent/Dubai spread to strengthen, reflecting weaker Dubai quotations. March Brent/Dubai was notionally assessed at $1.90/1.95.
Japanese refiners have covered their nearby requirements, ahead of their New Year holidays which start this weekend and last until January 6.
The American Petroleum Institute (API) will release its weekly oil inventory data later on Thursday instead of its regularly scheduled time of Tuesday evening, which was a holiday for the API.
